questions.text: Schwalbe’s line corresponds to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Descemets membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schwalbe’s line is the anatomical landmark that corresponds to the termination of Descemet's membrane in the eye.

questions.text: True about buphthalmos are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Shallow AC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In buphthalmos, the anterior chamber is deep (not shallow), and the definitive treatment is surgical intervention , making early diagnosis crucial.
  • ➤ deep
  • ➤ surgical intervention

questions.text: A 55 yrs old female comes to the eye casualty with history of severe eye pain, redness and diminution of vision. On examination the visual acuity Is 6/60, there is circurmcorneal congestion, corneal oedema and a shallow anterior chamber. Which of the following is the best drug of choice:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV mannitol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute angle-closure glaucoma, IV mannitol is the drug of choice for rapid reduction of IOP, followed by definitive treatment such as laser peripheral iridotomy or surgery.
  • ➤ IV mannitol

questions.text: A male patient with a history of hypermature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision and on examination has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye Is normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phacolytic glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacolytic glaucoma is associated with a hypermature cataract , an intact lens capsule, and a deep anterior chamber , caused by leakage of lens proteins leading to increased IOP and inflammation.
  • ➤ hypermature cataract
  • ➤ deep anterior chamber

questions.text: Malignant glaucoma is seen in:

options.label: B
options.text: After surgery for cataract or glaucoma

questions.correct_answer: B. After surgery for cataract or glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) After surgery for cataract or glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant glaucoma is seen after cataract or glaucoma surgery , and the primary treatment is atropine or other cycloplegics to manage aqueous misdirection.
  • ➤ after cataract or glaucoma surgery
  • ➤ atropine or other cycloplegics

questions.text: A lady with chronic simple glaucoma with bronchial asthma took anti glaucoma drug which exaggerated her asthma. The likely drug is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Timolol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Timolol, a non-selective beta-blocker , should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma as it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.
  • ➤ non-selective beta-blocker
  • ➤ bronchial asthma
  • ➤ bronchoconstriction

questions.text: Which of the following antiglaucoma medications can cause drowsiness:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brimonidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brimonidine can cause drowsiness and CNS effects due to its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier, making it unsuitable for use in children and professions requiring alertness, such as heavy vehicle operation.
  • ➤ Brimonidine
  • ➤ drowsiness

questions.text: Latanoprost used topically in glaucoma primarily acts by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increasing Uveo-scleral outflow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Latanoprost reduces intraocular pressure by increasing uveo-scleral outflow , making it a first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma.
  • ➤ increasing uveo-scleral outflow

questions.text: Argon laser trabeculoplasty is used in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary open glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT) is specifically used for primary open-angle glaucoma , where it reduces resistance to aqueous outflow through the trabecular meshwork.
  • ➤ Argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT)
  • ➤ primary open-angle glaucoma

questions.text: All are true about papilloedema except:

options.label: C
options.text: 1st sign is blurring of nasal side of optic disc

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sudden painful eye movement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papilloedema is a painless optic disc swelling caused by raised intracranial pressure, with the blurring of the nasal side of the optic disc being the earliest sign. Painful eye movements are not a feature of papilloedema and suggest other conditions like optic neuritis.
  • ➤ painless optic disc swelling
  • ➤ blurring of the nasal side of the optic disc
  • ➤ not a feature of papilloedema

questions.text: Paralysis of 3rd, 4th and 6th nerves with involvement of ophthalmic division of 5th nerve, localizes the lesion to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cavernous sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion causing paralysis of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI with involvement of the ophthalmic division of the 5th nerve (V1) is highly localized to the cavernous sinus , where all these nerves converge.
  • ➤ cavernous sinus

questions.text: Which is not a clinical feature of right sided VIth nerve palsy:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Face turn to left

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In right-sided VIth nerve palsy, the patient exhibits a medial convergent squint, inability to abduct the right eye, diplopia , and a face turn to the right to compensate. A face turn to the left is not a clinical feature.
  • ➤ medial convergent squint, inability to abduct the right eye, diplopia
  • ➤ face turn to the right
  • ➤ not

questions.text: In unilateral afferent pupillary defect, when light is moved from normal to affected eye there is:

options.label: A
options.text: Dilatation in affected eye and constriction in normal eye

options.label: B
options.text: Dilatation in normal eye and constriction in affected eye

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dilatation in both eyes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a unilateral afferent pupillary defect , when light is moved to the affected eye, both pupils dilate due to reduced afferent input from the damaged optic nerve or retina.
  • ➤ unilateral afferent pupillary defect
  • ➤ both pupils dilate

questions.text: Right eye superotemporal quadrantopla, left eye centrocaecal scotoma with headache. Site of lesion is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left optic nerve + chiasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A junctional scotoma involving the optic nerve and chiasma is classically characterized by a centrocecal scotoma in one eye (from optic nerve involvement) and a superotemporal quadrantanopia in the contralateral eye (from crossing nasal fibers at the chiasma).
  • ➤ junctional scotoma
  • ➤ optic nerve and chiasma
  • ➤ centrocecal scotoma
  • ➤ superotemporal quadrantanopia

questions.text: A case of injury to right brow due to a fall from scooter presents with sudden loss of vision in the right eye. The pupil shows absent direct reflex but a normal consensual pupillary reflex is present. The fundus is normal. The treatment of choice is:

options.label: A
options.text: Intensive intravenous corticosteroids as prescribed for spinal injuries to be instituted within six hours.

options.label: B
options.text: Pulse methylprednisolone 250 mg four times daily for three days.

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Emergency optic canal decompression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of traumatic optic neuropathy with features of optic nerve compression (RAPD, vision loss) , the treatment of choice is emergency optic canal decompression to relieve pressure on the optic nerve and restore vision.
  • ➤ traumatic optic neuropathy
  • ➤ optic nerve compression (RAPD, vision loss)
  • ➤ emergency optic canal decompression

questions.text: A female presented with breathlessness, arthralgia and blurring of vision with granulomatous anterior uveitis. Which is the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ocular sarcoidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ocular sarcoidosis is characterized by granulomatous uveitis, often accompanied by systemic features such as pulmonary and joint involvement.

questions.text: Pupil that responds to convergence but light reflex is absent:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Argyll Robertson pupil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Argyll Robertson pupil is characterized by a normal accommodation reflex but an absent light reflex (light-near dissociation) and is most commonly associated with neurosyphilis.

questions.text: Steroids are used in all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute dacryocystitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steroids are contraindicated in active infections like acute dacryocystitis because they can worsen the condition by suppressing the immune response.

questions.text: A recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis occurring with the onset of hot weather In young boys with symptoms of burning, itching and lacrimation with polygonal raised areas In palpebral conjunctiva is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis occurring in hot weather, characterized by cobblestone papillae, burning, itching, and lacrimation, primarily in young boys.

questions.text: All are fundus findings of diabetic retinopathy except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arteriolar dilatation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arteriolar dilatation is not a feature of diabetic retinopathy. Instead, look for microaneurysms, retinal haemorrhages, venous abnormalities, and neovascularisation.
  • ➤ Arteriolar dilatation is not a feature of diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Cherry-red spot is seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Krabbes disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cherry-red spots are seen in lysosomal storage disorders such as GM1 gangliosidosis, Niemann-Pick disease, and Sandhoff’s disease but not in Krabbe’s disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old executive presents with metamorphopsia in his right eye. On examination the fundus shows a shallow detachment at the macula. The fluoresce angiography shows a “smoke stack” sign. Which of the following management should be given:

options.label: B
options.text: Systemic corticosteroid for two weeks and then taper

options.label: C
options.text: Pulse Methyl prednisolone for three days and then taper

options.label: D
options.text: Just wait and watch for spontaneous recovery

questions.correct_answer: D. Just wait and watch for spontaneous recovery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Just wait and watch for spontaneous recovery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR) is managed by observing for spontaneous recovery unless the condition becomes chronic or severe. Corticosteroids are contraindicated as they can aggravate the condition.
  • ➤ Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR)

questions.text: While working in the neonatal ICU, your team delivers a premature infant at 27 weeks of gestation and weighing 1500 gm. How soon will you request fundus examination by an ophthalmologist:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3-4 weeks after delivery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For preterm infants, fundus examination should be conducted 3-4 weeks after birth or at 31-33 weeks postmenstrual age, whichever is earlier , to detect and manage ROP in a timely manner.
  • ➤ 3-4 weeks after birth or at 31-33 weeks postmenstrual age, whichever is earlier

questions.text: All are true regarding retinitis pigmentosa, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Early treatment prevents progression.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinitis pigmentosa is a progressive retinal disorder with no treatment to halt its progression, though vision preservation strategies are being researched. Visual acuity remains intact until late stages, and it may have multiple inheritance patterns or systemic associations.

questions.text: RD is diagnosed by all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3 mirror contact lens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinal detachment is diagnosed using tools like +90D lenses, direct ophthalmoscopy, and indirect ophthalmoscopy. A 3 mirror contact lens is not typically used for RD diagnosis.
  • ➤ 3 mirror contact lens

questions.text: Choroidal neovascularisation is seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypermetropia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choroidal neovascularisation occurs due to damage or breaks in the Bruch’s membrane, which can happen in conditions like myopia, trauma, and angioid streaks. Hypermetropia is not associated with CNV.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about phthisis bulbi:

options.label: B
options.text: Calcification of the lens is common

options.label: D
options.text: Size of the globe is reduced

questions.correct_answer: A. The intraocular pressure is increased
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The intraocular pressure is increased

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phthisis bulbi is a shrunken, non-functional eye characterized by low intraocular pressure, thickened sclera, calcification, and reduced globe size. The intraocular pressure is never increased in this condition.

questions.text: “Headlight - In Fog Appearance” of retina is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Headlight - In Fog Appearance" of the retina is a hallmark finding of ocular toxoplasmosis , characterized by a bright white lesion (headlight) amidst hazy vitreous inflammation (fog).
  • ➤ ocular toxoplasmosis

questions.text: Fasanella-Servat operation is specifically indicated in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Horners syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Fasanella-Servat operation is specifically indicated for mild ptosis with good levator function , especially in cases of Horner's syndrome , where the ptosis results from Müller’s muscle dysfunction.
  • ➤ Fasanella-Servat operation
  • ➤ mild ptosis with good levator function
  • ➤ Horner's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false:

options.label: A
options.text: External hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland

options.label: B
options.text: Internal hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland

options.label: C
options.text: Internal hordeolum is an acute suppurative inflammation of meibomian gland

options.label: D
options.text: Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibornian gland

questions.correct_answer: B. Internal hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Internal hordeolum is an acute inflammation of the Zeis gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Internal hordeolum involves the Meibomian glands. External hordeolum involves the Zeis glands. Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland.
  • ➤ Internal hordeolum involves the Meibomian glands.
  • ➤ Internal hordeolum
  • ➤ External hordeolum involves the Zeis glands.
  • ➤ External hordeolum
  • ➤ Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland.
  • ➤ Chalazion

questions.text: Most common malignant tumor of eyelid:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelid, while squamous cell carcinoma is the second most common. Sebaceous cell carcinoma, although rare, should be suspected in cases of recurrent chalazion.
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma
  • ➤ squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with watering from his left eye since one year. Syringing revealed a patent drainage system. Rest of ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure was made. Confirmation of the diagnosis would be by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dacryoscintigraphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dacryoscintigraphy is the most appropriate test to confirm lacrimal pump failure , as it evaluates the functional drainage of the lacrimal system when the anatomical patency is intact.
  • ➤ Dacryoscintigraphy
  • ➤ lacrimal pump failure

questions.text: In DCR the drainage is in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Middle meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) , the surgical drainage is directed to the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.
  • ➤ Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)
  • ➤ middle meatus

questions.text: Limited abduction & adduction is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type 3 Duane’s retraction syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 3 Duane’s retraction syndrome is characterized by limited abduction and adduction , caused by abnormal innervation of both lateral and medial rectus muscles.
  • ➤ Type 3 Duane’s retraction syndrome
  • ➤ limited abduction and adduction

questions.text: A 23-year old male presents with progressive proptosis of his right eye. The proptosis increases on bending forward and is compressible. No thrill or bruit was present. Orbital ultrasound revealed an echogenic mass with foci of echo shadows. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital varix

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orbital varix is the most common cause of compressible, positional proptosis and is characterized by worsening of proptosis during maneuvers that increase venous pressure, without associated thrill or bruit.
  • ➤ Orbital varix
  • ➤ compressible, positional proptosis

questions.text: The most common posterior segment pathology responsible for diminished vision in anterior uveitis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cystoid Macular edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of vision loss in anterior uveitis is cystoid macular edema (CME) , which results from inflammation disrupting the blood-retinal barrier and causing macular swelling.
  • ➤ cystoid macular edema (CME)

questions.text: Most common cause of Vitreous Hemorrhage in diabetic retinopathy is:

options.label: D
options.text: Trauma leading to rupture of Central retinal artery

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neovascularization of disc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) , the most common cause of vitreous hemorrhage is neovascularization of the disc (NVD) , resulting from ischemia-induced fragile blood vessel formation.
  • ➤ proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • ➤ neovascularization of the disc (NVD)

questions.text: What is represented by ETDRS in a diabetic vision chart:

options.label: B
options.text: Extended treatment for diabetes review study

options.label: C
options.text: Extensive therapy for diabetes research study

questions.correct_answer: A. Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ETDRS refers to the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study , a pivotal clinical trial that set the standards for managing diabetic retinopathy and macular edema, and introduced the widely used ETDRS vision chart.
  • ➤ ETDRS
  • ➤ Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study

questions.text: Enucleation of the eyeball is contraindicated in
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Panophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enucleation is contraindicated in panophthalmitis due to the risk of spreading infection to the CNS via the optic nerve's meninges. In these cases, exenteration is the safer alternative.
  • ➤ contraindicated in panophthalmitis
  • ➤ exenteration

questions.text: Blow out fracture orbit is characterized by all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Exophthalmos

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exophthalmos is not a characteristic of blow-out fractures of the orbit; instead, it may lead to enophthalmos or diplopia due to muscle entrapment and orbital content displacement.
  • ➤ Exophthalmos
  • ➤ blow-out fractures
  • ➤ enophthalmos

questions.text: Following muscles originate from ring of zinn except
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inferior oblique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inferior oblique muscle is the only extraocular muscle that does not originate from the ring of Zinn ; instead, it arises from the medial wall of the orbit near the maxillary bone .
  • ➤ inferior oblique
  • ➤ ring of Zinn
  • ➤ medial wall of the orbit near the maxillary bone

questions.text: Downward and nasal subluxation of lens is typically seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Homocystinuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Downward and nasal subluxation of the lens is a hallmark feature of homocystinuria , distinguishing it from Marfan's syndrome, where lens subluxation is upward and temporal .
  • ➤ Downward and nasal subluxation of the lens
  • ➤ homocystinuria
  • ➤ upward and temporal

questions.text: In Keratoconus all are seen except:

options.label: C
options.text: Distortion of corneal reflex at center

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypermetropic refractive error found

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keratoconus is associated with myopia and irregular astigmatism , not hypermetropia . Hypermetropic refractive error is not a feature of keratoconus.
  • ➤ myopia and irregular astigmatism
  • ➤ hypermetropia

questions.text: Which of the following is true about dendritic ulcer:

options.label: B
options.text: Topical corticosteroid given suppresses the symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: Oral acyclovir is effective in treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. Caused by Herpes simplex virus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Caused by Herpes simplex virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A dendritic ulcer is caused by the Herpes simplex virus and presents as branching lesions on the cornea. Topical antiviral agents are the primary treatment, while corticosteroids are contraindicated to avoid worsening the infection.
  • ➤ dendritic ulcer
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus
  • ➤ Topical antiviral agents

questions.text: Muscle earliest involved in thyroid ophthalmopathy:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inferior rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inferior rectus muscle is the earliest and most commonly involved muscle in thyroid ophthalmopathy , leading to restricted upward gaze and vertical diplopia.
  • ➤ inferior rectus muscle
  • ➤ thyroid ophthalmopathy

questions.text: Keratometer is used to assess:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Curvature of cornea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A keratometer is primarily used to assess the curvature of the cornea , which is critical for contact lens fitting, evaluating astigmatism, and planning refractive surgeries.
  • ➤ keratometer
  • ➤ curvature of the cornea

questions.text: Best site for IOL implantation:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Capsular bag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The capsular bag is the best and most preferred site for IOL implantation , providing optimal positioning, stability, and reduced postoperative complications.
  • ➤ capsular bag
  • ➤ IOL implantation

questions.text: Polychromatic lusture is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior subcapsular cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polychromatic lustre is a distinctive feature of posterior subcapsular cataracts (PSC) , along with breadcrumb appearance, axial spread, and posterior subcapsular location.
  • ➤ Polychromatic lustre
  • ➤ posterior subcapsular cataracts (PSC)

questions.text: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological examination to exclude possibility of
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A recurrent chalazion should always be subjected to histopathological examination to rule out sebaceous cell carcinoma , a potentially aggressive malignancy that mimics benign eyelid conditions.
  • ➤ recurrent chalazion
  • ➤ sebaceous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Ptosis occurs due to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oculomotor palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ptosis occurs due to oculomotor nerve palsy , as it innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle , responsible for elevating the upper eyelid.
  • ➤ Ptosis
  • ➤ oculomotor nerve palsy
  • ➤ levator palpebrae superioris muscle
